FacilityStr1: 4 Miles W. of Kincaid on Route 104

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Odor first indicator of small leak
_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: All instruments - annual calibration and testing.  Fog system tested (flow).  NDE on tanks, pumps, vaporizers, & piping.  All gaskets replaced.  All safety and relief valves replaced.  ESS tested.
_prev_prog_3.Description: COMPANY'S PREVENTION PROGRAM:  The company's prevention program is based on OSHA's Process Safety Management standard.  Kincaid Generation, L.L.C. has never had a reportable release of ammonia.  It does have an emergency response plan which meets OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.120 (HAZWOPER) and accidental releases are expected to be corrected immediately by employees of Kincaid Generation, L.L.C.  Notification of an accidental release will be immediatelymade to the Christian County LEPC/Emergency Services contact.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
DESCRIPTION OF FACILITY AND RELATED PROCESSES:  Kincaid Generation L.L.C. is an electric utility generating facility, which burns coal to generate electricity.  The facility uses Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) in order to comply with nitrogen oxides (NOx) emission reductions required by the Illinois Section 217 Subpart V NOx Rule and U.S. EPA's Regional NOx SIP Call, as implemented through Illinois Section 217 Subpart W Rule.  The SCR process consists of injecting anhydrous ammonia into the boiler flue gas.  The gas then goes through a catalyst bed where the nitrogen oxides react to form nitrogen and water vapor.  This Risk Management Plan covers the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia.

WORST CASE RELEASE SCENARIO:  The worst case release scenario is defined by EPA to be a rupture of one ammonia storage tank, with its entire contents being released as a ten-minute gas release at ground level.  Based on the DEGADIS+ model as distributed through Trinity Consultants' BREEZE HAZ software for calculating the consequences of such a release at 3,825 gal/min (21,750 lbs/min), ammonia could travel as much as 3.0 miles before being diluted to the toxic endpoint. 

ALTERNATE RELEASE SCENARIOS:  A more likely release scenario is a small hole in a flexible transfer hose during tank truck unloading operations.  The unloading system is equipped with excess flow valves that will stop unloading in the event of total hose failure, however, a small hole in the hose or a gasket may not be automatically detected.  If the hole were 1/4 inch diameter, the ammonia release is estimated to be 30 gal/min (170 lbs/min).  The toxic endpoint for such a scenario is 0.27 miles.  A second alternative scenario with a continuous release through a 1/8 inch diameter hole in a 2 inch transfer line (representing a broken pressure gauge tap or a packing leak around a valve stem) was evaluated and the result was of a significantly lower consequence.  Elevated jet plume releases were also evalua

ted, but found to have no ground level concentrations at or above the toxic endpoint for ammonia.

COMPANY'S PREVENTION PROGRAM:  The company's prevention program is based on OSHA's Process Safety Management standard.  Kincaid Generation, L.L.C. has never had a reportable release of ammonia.  It does have an emergency response plan which meets OSHA standards at 29 CFR 1910.120 (HAZWOPER) and accidental releases are expected to be corrected immediately by employees of Kincaid Generation, L.L.C.  Notification of an accidental release will be immediately made to the Christian County LEPC/Emergency Services contact.
